awd_titl_txt: Investigation of the triple oxygen isotope systematics of shales in the Precambrian
awd_abstract_narration:
Shale is a major sedimentary rock type that records the composition of the Earth's crust and its weathering. As the process of weathering proceeds with a great excess of water, the oxygen isotope value in shales reflects the isotopic value of water interacting with the rock and the temperature of weathering. Using triple oxygen isotopes (17O/16O versus 18O/16O) systematics in the main sedimentary rock type, shale and associated diagenetic silica, the investigator proposes to gain insight into paleoenvironmental and weathering conditions during early Earth's history. His collection of shales covers 3.5 billion years and spans the major snowball Earth glacial and greenhouse episodes, the Great Oxidation Event, the Neoproterozoic appearance of multicellular life in oceans, and the appearance of life on land. As part of the educational component, this project will support a graduate student. As an outreach of this effort, the investigator will lead a one-day workshop at the American Geophysical meeting in San Francisco in 2020, to which he will invite colleagues working on this topic, as well as those interested in the advent of precise microanalytical and rare isotope methods for the Precambrian. He will additionally develop a set of standards for 17O that span a large range in delta 18O and delta 17O values for cross-laboratory calibration purposes and make it available to the community for analysis of sedimentary and other materials.

The project will: 1) make measurements, using the investigator's newly constructed high-precision 17O extraction line, of a collection of shales across geologic history that has been previously characterized for delta 18O, Titanium isotopes, and chemical composition; 2) describe long-term and geological interval-specific, triple oxygen trends of maturing lithosphere, evolving hydrosphere and/or increasing continental subaerial extent; 3) examine triple oxygen signatures of quartz within shales and zircons through time, and 4) build a geochemical box model of coupled hydrosphere-crustal evolution with additional 17O input parameters that will permit resolution of previous controversies related to hotter environments in the Archean versus low delta 18O hydrosphere based on their measurements and those generated by other laboratories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The proposal looked at evolution of Early Earth environments to constrain surface conditions (temperature, isotopic value of oceans) coupled with evolution of the continental crust and subcontinental mantle. We used multiple dated materials: shales, cherts, granites, and peridotites to answer these questions using our newly developed triple oxygen isotopic methods. Via new measurements, we discovered an increase in oxygen isotopic values of shales and granites through time, and a decrease in values in upper mantle peridotites of continental roots that are explained by progression of plate tectonics and growth of continental crust. We additionally investigated the same collection of shales for their Nd and Hf isotopes and discovered that these two isotopic systems start diverging after the appearance of oxygen in the air (Great Oxidation Event) at about 2.4 Ga. Thus, the advent of oxidative weathering on Earth is recorded by these isotopic proxies. We have additionally studied the world’s oldest rocks on Earth the Nuvvuagittuq belt, Canada that are made of pillow basalts of 4.3 Ga old, covered with coeval sediments. The research on ancient hydrothermally-altered rocks help us gain better insight into conditions in the oceans and Earth’s surface. Using novel triple oxygen isotopic measurements, we further demonstrated the presence of glacial meltwater in sedimentology of the world’s oldest glaciation in Pongola, S Africa, proving the word’s first glaciation at 2.9 Ga

We have also investigated modern clays from all many modern rivers around the world, and weathering profiles in Oregon. We demonstrated that suspended clays in modern rivers broadly reflect triple oxygen isotope equilibrium at temperatures and isotopic values of their respective watersheds, an important test for past environments. 

Via modeling, we used results of new triple oxygen isotopic measurements as input parameters to suggest the possibility of the change of oxygen isotopic value of seawater while keeping the surface conditions comparable to modern. The effort continues to account for irreversible fluxes of water into the mantle, and its effects on the emergence of land and weathering.

Project resulted in two book Chapters and 15 papers, an international workshop and a Reviews in Mineralogy and Geochemistry review volume. It supported two graduate students, a Fulbright research visitor, and contributed to maintaining the analytical infrastructure of the Stable Isotope Lab at the University of Oregon, including the variety of related collaborative projects performed in the lab. PI gave 12 talks and outreach lectures in the US and five different countries.

 Evolution of surface environments and growth and maturation of the continental crust that we study here has direct connection to evolution of life forms on Earth, a fascinating topic for general public and general education. Furthermore, the appearance of oxygen on land at 2.4 Ga, so called the Great Oxidation Event has roots in the research we perform here. Our knowledge of past conditions on Earth is relevant for other planets and also for the Earth’s future.
